sen.j: 九条 忠教（くじょう ただのり、宝治2年（1248年） - 正慶元年/元弘2年12月6日 (旧暦)（1332年12月24日））は鎌倉時代の公卿、従一位・関白、通称は報恩院殿。
sen.e: Tadanori KUJO (1248 - December 24, 1332), a court noble who lived in the Kamakura period, became Kanpaku at Juichii (junior first rank) and was commonly called Hoonin-dono.

Tadanori KUJO (1248 - December 24, 1332) was a court noble of the Kamakura period, reaching the position of Kanpaku (chief advisor to the emperor) and Juichii (junior first rank); he was commonly called Hoonin-dono.

Tadanori KUJO (1248 - January 1, 1333) was a court noble of the Kamakura period, reaching the position of Kanpaku (chief advisor to the emperor) and Juichii (Junior First Rank); he was commonly called Hoonin-dono.
sen.cmt: ユリウス→グレゴリオ暦に修正、「従一位」の表記を修正

sen.e: His father was Tadaie KUJO.
His father was Tadaie KUJO.
His father was Tadaie KUJO.
He was a grandson of Norizane KUJO.
He was a grandson of Norizane KUJO.
He was a grandson of Norizane KUJO.

sen.j: 正室は西園寺公相の娘、側室は二条道良の娘。
sen.e: His legal wife was a daughter of Kinsuke SAIONJI and a daughter of Michinaga NIJO was his concubine.
His legal wife was a daughter of Kinsuke SAIONJI and his concubine was a daughter of Michinaga NIJO.
His legal wife was a daughter of Kinsuke SAIONJI and his concubine was a daughter of Michinaga NIJO.

sen.j: 子に九条師教、九条房実、二条兼基室。
sen.e: Moronori KUJO, Fusazane KUJO and a concubine of Kanemoto NIJO were his children.
Moronori KUJO, Fusazane KUJO and a concubine of Kanemoto NIJO were his children.
Moronori KUJO, Fusazane KUJO and a wife of Kanemoto NIJO were his children.
sen.cmt: concubine of Kanemoto NIJO→「室」の記載のみのため、wife of Kanemoto NIJOとしました。

sen.j: 近江国にあった藤原不比等の別荘跡に忠教が現在の安楽寺 (長浜市)を建てる。
sen.e: Tadanori built present Anraku-ji Temple (in Nagahama City) at the site where the FUJIWARA no Fuhito's villa in the Omi province was once placed.
Tadanori built present-day Anraku-ji Temple (in Nagahama City) on the site of FUJIWARA no Fuhito's villa in Omi Province.
Tadanori built present-day Anraku-ji Temple (in Nagahama City) on the site of FUJIWARA no Fuhito's villa in Omi Province.

sen.j: 弘長2年（1262年）1月5日 (旧暦)叙従三位に任官。
sen.e: On January 5 (in the old calendar), 1262, he was given Jusani (junior third rank) and assumed a government post with the rank.
On January 5 (lunar calendar), 1262, he was promoted to Jusani (junior third rank).
On February 2, 1262, he was promoted to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank).
sen.cmt: 旧暦→新暦に修正、「従三位」の表記を修正

sen.j: 正安元年（1299年）、平安時代の京都六条河原にあった源融公邸跡地を歓喜光寺歴史に寄進して、忠教が現在地に善導寺を移らせて、歓喜光寺とした。
sen.e: In 1299, the former MINAMOTO no Toru's residence site once located in Rokujo-gawara of Kyotoin the Heian period was donated to Rekihumi KANKIKOJI, and Tadanori moved Zendo-ji Temple to the present site, changing the name to Kankiko-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 歓喜光寺歴史： 何を意味するのか、意味が理解できませんでした。一応、人名としてそれらしい、読み方をしてみました。
sen.e: In 1299, the site of MINAMOTO no Toru's Heian Period residence, located in Kyoto's Rokujo-gawara, was donated to Rekihumi KANKIKOJI, and Tadanori moved Zendo-ji Temple to its present site, changing the name to Kankiko-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - though like the translator, I have no idea what is meant by "歓喜光寺歴史"
sen.e: In 1299, the site of MINAMOTO no Toru's Heian period residence, located in Kyoto's Rokujo-gawara, was donated to Zendo-ji Temple, and Tadanori moved Zendo-ji Temple to its present site, changing the name to Kankiko-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 「歓喜光寺歴史」→ウェブ上で確認したところ、正しくは「善導寺」であったため、こちらに基づき訳文を修正しました。(「歓喜光寺歴史」はリンク先の用語のようです)Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更

sen.j: 延慶 (日本)2年（1309年）に忠教は出家して、戒名を円阿と称する。
sen.e: In 1309, Tadanori became a priest and his posthumous Buddhist name was Ena.
sen.cmt: 戒名: ”僧としての名前”としないと不自然な気がしましたが、字句どおりに訳してあります。
